Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Technology Pathway Program in Data Technology and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing an interdisciplinary technology pathway program (TPP) in data technology and applications for behavioral, social, and health science students at two California State Universities. It consists of four technical courses covering Python programming, data structures and algorithms, data technology, and an interdisciplinary senior project (or database). It will be offered as a minor degree program as part of bachelor's degree programs, or as a certificate program. The TPP program will use evidence-based teaching practices that encompass effective pedagogy as well as learning communities and faculty professional development. The program will use contextualized problem-based pedagogy in which students acquire key technical knowledge and skills by solving real-world problems. Each cohort of participating students will be formed into a learning community that will include professors and industry professionals in Silicon Valley for student support and role-modeling. The engineering and computing faculty who will teach the students in this program will engage in professional development in order to learn pedagogical approaches that have been shown effective for the diverse students in the social, behavioral, and health sciences. These faculty have agreed to participate in a Faculty Learning Community throughout the academic year and a summer Technology Pathway Summer Institute.

The project is expected to generate research contributions towards the development of a technical education program for a diverse group of students and the creation of a sustainable interdisciplinary program that crosses internal organizational boundaries and links to external sponsors. If this project succeeds, it will very likely spur other campuses to develop similar programs through faculty development and dissemination plans. The ongoing evaluation of the propagation process and its outcomes will reveal valuable lessons for launching such interdisciplinary initiatives. One of the participating institutions is a minority serving institution.

Institution.Name: California State University, East Bay Foundation, Inc.
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, EAST BAY FOUNDATION, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: California State University, East Bay Foundation, Inc.

ProgramReference.Text: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project develops an interdisciplinary technology pathway program (TPP) in data technology and applications for behavioral and health science majors at California State University East Bay (CSUEB). This TPP program's major goal is to help Health Science majors and non-STEM students to acquire STEM education, therefore expand their career opportunities and increase future income for the students. During the project period, CSUEB faculty from different departments had been working collaboratively on proposing and developing six new interdisciplinary computing courses and a new data technology certificate program for the behavioral and health science majors as well as non-STEM students. This project utilized evidence-based educational practices that encompass effective pedagogy, learning communities, and faculty development.

Intellectual Merit:

The project generates research contributions in (1) development of a technical education program for a diverse group of students, and (2) creation of a sustainable interdisciplinary curricular program that crosses organizational boundaries. The TPP program applies research results on improving the education of STEM students to teaching technical subjects to non-STEM students. It is of great value to analyze factors that correlate with success for a diverse group of students. Moreover, it can stimulus other campuses to develop similar programs through faculty development and dissemination plans. The ongoing evaluation of the propagation process and its outcomes reveals valuable lessons for launching such interdisciplinary initiatives.

Broader Impacts: 

The proposed interdisciplinary curricular program presents an innovative approach to providing technology education to diverse non-STEM students, thus broadening its breadth of participation. Graduates from this program are better prepared to apply technical skills to generate new knowledge in behavioral, social, and health sciences through data collection, analysis, and visualization of big data. The program outcomes and models can be broadly disseminated and systematically propagated. Partnerships have been created among universities, industry, and government. Ultimately, as more campuses develop similar interdisciplinary curricular programs, more students will gain the technical education that benefits themselves and the nation.


Last Modified: 01/25/2021
Modified by: Jiaofei Zhong
